ENE280.name: Principles of Environmental Engineering and Science
ENE280.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENE280.description: Physical, chemical and biological processes related to environmental science and engineering. Environmental systems analysis with application to air, water and soil. Analysis of environmental problems and development of engineering solutions.
ENE280.prerequisite: (CEM 141 or CEM 151 or LB 171) and ((MTH 132 or concurrently) or (MTH 152H or concurrently) or (LB 118 or concurrently))

ENE421.name: Engineering Hydrology
ENE421.description: Hydrologic design of storm water systems. Equilibrium hydrograph analysis, unit hydrographs, infiltration, hydrograph synthesis, and reservoir routing. Groundwater
ENE421.prerequisite: (CE 321) and (GLG 201 or GLG 301) and (CE 372 or STT 351)
ENE421.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the College of Engineering or in the College of Natural Science or in the Department of Plant, Soil and Microbial Sciences.

ENE422.name: Applied Hydraulics
ENE422.description: Fundamentals of open-channel flow. Rapidly and gradually varied nonuniform flow analysis. Confined flows past submerged bodies, in pipe networks, and in turbo machinery. Design applications.
ENE422.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the College of Engineering.

ENE480.name: Environmental Measurements Laboratory
ENE480.description: Basic chemical and microbiological methods used in the analysis of environmental media. Laboratory safety, quality assurance, quality control, and statistics used in laboratory analysis. Related technical communication, laboratory report writing.
ENE480.prerequisite: (CEM 161 or CEM 185H or LB 171L) and ENE 280 and (CEM 142 or CEM 152 or CEM 182H or LB 172) and ((ENE 481 or concurrently) or (ENE 483 or concurrently)) and Completion of Tier I Writing Requirement
ENE480.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the College of Engineering.

ENE481.name: Environmental Chemistry: Equilibrium Concepts
ENE481.description: Chemistry of natural environmental systems and pollutants. Equilibrium concepts and calculations for acid-base, solubility, complexion, redox and phase partitioning reactions and processes. Applications to ecosystem analysis, pollutant fate and transport, and environmental protection.
ENE481.prerequisite: {(CEM 141 and CEM 142) or (CEM 151 and CEM 152) or (CEM 181H and CEM 182H) or (LB 171 and LB 172)} and (ENE 280 or BE 230 or GLG 201 or GLG 301 or approval of department)

ENE483.name: Water and Wastewater Engineering
ENE483.description: Engineering and scientific basis and design of physical, chemical and biological methods for the treatment of drinking water and wastewater. Operation process selection and design. Field trips required.
ENE483.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the College of Engineering.

ENE484.name: Water Resource Recovery Engineering
ENE484.description: Municipal, industrial, and rural wastewater characteristics. Selection of best site- and management-specific treatment strategy, including the influence of governmental policy and societal needs.
ENE484.prerequisite: BE 360 or (ENE 487 or concurrently) or approval of department
ENE484.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources or in the College of Engineering.

ENE485.name: Landfill Design
ENE485.description: Geotechnical and environmental design of solid waste landfills.

ENE487.name: Microbiology for Environmental Science and Engineering
ENE487.description: Fundamentals of microbiology. Application of these concepts to environmental processes such as wastewater treatment, human health and bioremediation.

ENE489.name: Air Pollution: Science and Engineering
ENE489.description: Basic physical and chemical principles governing indoor and atmospheric air pollution. Elements of air pollution meteorology, climate change, atmospheric transformations and transport. Air pollution sources and methods for their control. The role of local, state and federal government in air pollution control.
ENE489.prerequisite: (CEM 141 or CEM 151 or LB 171) and (MTH 133 or MTH 153H or LB 119) and (ENE 280 or BE 230) and (CE 321 or CHE 311)
ENE489.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors or graduate students in the College of Engineering.

ENE490.name: Independent Study
ENE490.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ENE490.description: Environmental engineering problem of specific interest to the student and a faculty member. May be analysis or design.
ENE490.restrictions: Open to juniors or seniors in the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering. Approval of department.

ENE492.name: Selected Topics in Environmental Engineering
ENE492.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENE492.description: Selected topics related to environmental engineering, fluid mechanics and hydrology.

ENE800.name: Environmental Engineering Seminar
ENE800.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year
ENE800.restrictions: Open only to Environmental Engineering majors.

ENE801.name: Dynamics of Environmental Systems
ENE801.description: Principles of mass balance, reaction kinetics, mass transfer, reactor theory in environmental engineering.

ENE802.name: Physicochemical Processes in Environmental Engineering
ENE802.description: Physical and chemical principles of air and water pollution control and environmental contaminants in water, air and soils.

ENE803.name: Water Quality and Public Health
ENE803.description: Principles, applications, and latest research in the area of water quality and public health. Various chemical and microbiological water contaminants and their health effects. Concepts of public health and epidemiology, principles of toxicology, exposure characterization and risk assessment approaches, water management alternatives, and global issues of concern.

ENE804.name: Biological Processes in Environmental Engineering
ENE804.description: Engineering of microbial processes used in wastewater treatment, in-situ bioreclamation, and solid waste stabilization.

ENE805.name: Contaminated Site Remediation
ENE805.description: Key topics within contaminated site remediation. Regulations relevant to remediation. Site characterization and assessment. Removal technologies, mechanisms involved, variations in approaches, advantages and limitations. Case studies for each method. Overview of air treatment technologies. Remediation approaches for problematic groundwater contaminants.

ENE806.name: Environmental Engineering Process Laboratory
ENE806.description: Development of skills related to planning, design, and execution of processes related to environmental engineering, enhance decision making skills, teamwork, analysis of data, report writing, and oral presentation.
ENE806.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Environmental Engineering major.

ENE821.name: Groundwater Hydraulics
ENE821.description: Physical properties of porous media. Equations of flow in saturated media. Flow nets, well flow and parameter measurement. Transport processes and the advective-dispersion equation for conservative contaminants.

ENE822.name: Groundwater Modeling
ENE822.description: Analysis and modeling of groundwater flow, surface water and groundwater interaction, and reactive contaminant transport. Applied numerical methods for solving groundwater flow and contaminant transport equations. Case studies.

ENE829.name: Mixing and Transport in Surface Waters
ENE829.description: Waves, tides and shallow-water processes. Numerical solutions and applications of shallow-water equations to lakes, rivers and estuaries. Principles and processes of sediment transport, and dispersion of materials in surface waters. Wind-driven circulation in Lake Michigan.

ENE880.name: Independent Study in Environmental Engineering
ENE880.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ENE880.description: Solution of environmental engineering problems not related to student's thesis.
ENE880.restrictions: Open only to Environmental Engineering majors.

ENE890.name: Selected Topics in Environmental Engineering
ENE890.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ENE890.description: Selected topics in new or developing areas of environmental engineering.
ENE890.restrictions: Open to students in the Environmental Engineering major.

ENE892.name: Master's Research Project
ENE892.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
ENE892.description: Master's degree Plan B individual student research project. Original research, research replication, or survey and reporting on a research topic.
ENE892.restrictions: Open only to master's students in the Environmental Engineering major. Approval of department.

ENE899.name: Master's Thesis Research
ENE899.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year

ENE900.name: Research Strategies and Methods in Environmental Engineering and Science
ENE900.description: Criteria for quality research, scientific method, scientific arguments, statistical testing, critical thinking skills, reviewing journal articles, literature synthesis, writing proposals and papers, giving presentations, responsible conduct of research.
ENE900.restrictions: Open to graduate students in the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering and open to graduate students in the Department of Geological Sciences.

ENE999.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
ENE999.semester: Fall of every year, Spring of every year, Summer of every year
